abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Irrigation
            Rehabilitation and Reform Project for Romania were as
            follows: overall outcome was moderately unsatisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was substantial, the Bank
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and the borrower
            performance was unsatisfactory. There were some important
            project lessons learned. Where difficult reforms and
            entrenched interests are involved, the Bank should require
            more concrete evidence of commitment to the project's
            objectives before approval. As such, the Law on Land
            Reclamation should have been made a condition of
            negotiations rather than a condition of effectiveness.
            During implementation, when it became clear that the
            government commitment to the project was no longer there,
            the Bank should have acted more proactively to suspend or
            drastically restructure the project. The economic analysis
            of projects under preparation should be used as an iterative
            planning and design tool, rather than as a simple requisite
            to justify pre-defined investments. Project impact could be
            significantly enhanced and failures reduced, as the best
            investment alternatives are better checked and identified at appraisal.
